text: Barbara alone on a bench. She is high above the city, the view is magnificent. She watches the couples, kids playing, families.
People have always trusted me with their secrets.
Barbara writing her diary in her one bedroom, basement fl
But who do I trust with mine? A whole shelf of hardback notebooks, her collection of diaries dating back to the 1950’s.
You. Only you.

The roar of traffic. The urban ravine of the Archway Road The red, black and gold cast-iron ‘suicide bridge’ which straddles it. Barbara driving to work in her old W Polo. EXT. ST GEORGE’S SCHOOL/CAR PARK —- MORNING The school is a bleak, Victorian building with various mo add-ons. Barbara locks her car and heads for the main entrance. INT. CLASSROOM —- MINUTES LATER Barbara takes out her lesson planner, text books, registr She organizes them neatly on her desk. Barbara stares at the rows of empty desks and chairs.
The first day of a new term. Sound of PUPILS arriving outside. Barbara observes them f her high window.
Kids in school uniform stream through the gates.
Here come the local pubescent proles. They play football, gossip, fight and skirmish. A diverse ethnic mix, about fifty percent white.

The future shop assistants and plumbers. And doubtless the odd terrorist too. A teacher (BRIAN) oversees the general activity. SHEBA HART comes in through the main gates pushing her ta old bicycle. She looks a little lost. Brian directs her to the bike racks.
Barbara watches TED MAWSON (Deputy Head) outside with She he’s introducing her to MEMBERS OF STAFF passing by.
In the old days we confiscated cigarettes and ‘wank mags’. Now it’s knives and crack cocaine. And they call it progress. The school bell rings and Sheba is whisked away in anothe direction.

Barbara writes ‘Wittenberg’ on the board. Other stray phr already there: ‘Diet of worms’ ‘Martin Luther’. She’s teaching ‘The Reformation’ to a class of bored 16 y olds. The bell rings. The kids immediately snatch up their hook leave. Barbara makes a gesture - they sit back down.
(under his breath) Fuckin’ poison granny. Barbara surveys her class. Another gesture: ‘you may go’.

A committee meeting of around TWENTY TEACHERS chaired by Headmaster, SANDY PABBLEM. His secretary (GITA) takes notes. The staff sit in chairs a circle, Barbara amongst them. In passing we see teacher ELAINE CLIFFORD and SUE HODGE.

Before we start, can those of you who haven’t delivered your reports please lob ‘em in my general direction. He goes round the circle. Staff hand him their school iss report files, all thick with their work.
Thanks Bill, Elaine. Thank you, Linda - how’s Greg?
A bit better, thanks. He holds his hands together - a gesture of emotional solidarity.
Good, good. Sheba comes in mouthing apologies for her lateness.
Ah! Has everyone met our new Art teacher, Sheba Hart? General murmars of ‘hello’ and ‘welcome’.

I’ve invited Sheba to sit in on this meeting. As you know, I regard The Arts as absolutely central to our policy of ‘reform through nurture.’ Barbara gestures to the empty chair beside her. But anot teacher (BILL RUMER) is comically commanding Sheba to sit next to him. Which she does.
Welcome to you. Sheba takes out a note-pad and pen, looking nervous but k Pabblem continues collecting the reports.
Thank you, Sue. Ooh, that’s a big one! I’1ll be up ‘til the crack of dawn. Anyone else not handed in their homework? He turns to Barbara, a hint of nervousness.

Barbara...? Barbara coolly produces her file. It’s impossibly thin. Pabblem pretends to weigh it on his hand go that others c witness its paucity. Encouraged by polite laughter he opens it to reveal a sin sheet of typed paper.
This is your report? On the History Department? On its entire workings? And your general thoughts for its future development?

You’ll find it’s quite thorough, Headmaster. The teachers look tense but one or two are secretly amuse this is vintage Barbara. Gita looks appalled. Pabblem stares at the report; it’s one paragraph long.

(reads aloud) ‘The History Department functions much as one would expect for a school of this stature and intake. Examination results have been consistent for thirty years; below the national average but above the level of catastrophe. Recommendation: no change necessary’. Barbara looks innocent, defying Pabblem to explode-
It took me most of the summer to write it. He stares at her in impotent fury. Barbara sneaks a look at Sheba.
Hard to read the wispy novice. Is she a sphinx or simply stupid?
Sheba on playground duty, wrapped in a coat, she’s patrol amongst the children. Barbara lurks nearby.
Artfully dishevelled today. The tweedy tramp coat is an abhorrence. It seems to say, ‘I’m just like you’. But clearly she is not. Sheba intervenes between two kids sparring for a fight.

A fey person, I suspect. Fey. suddenly - a roar from some BOYS playing football. The go scorer, a BOY of fifteen, celebrates by whipping his shir off and waving it in jubilation - naked from the waist up
Put your shirt on!
I got the winner, Miss!
Glory be. Shirt. Barbara glances at Sheba. She seems to be looking straigh her. Barbara wonders if Sheba disapproves her ticking off boy. As he runs away:
Good goal!
Barbara with her tray cating lunch.
She has certainly rippled the waters of our stagnant pond. They flock to her. She watches Brian approaching Sheba.
Even limp, little Brian had a go. Oh, the ‘ horror. Other TEACHERS, almost queuing for Sheba’s attention. :

And Fatty Hodge has pounced on her. Barbara at a grubby canteen table - watching with a seemi benign smile. Sheba and SUE HODGE are on a bench outside, bathed in sunlight as they eat their sandwiches.
A dubious double-act; the blonde and the pig in knickers. Sue chews like a rabbit as Sheba chortles.
Barbara on a break. A few other TEACHERS dotted around. B comes in looking a little sheepish.
I just went past the Art Studio... Barbara glances up- BRIAN . It’s bloody Lord of the Flies in there.
Have they gone for her?

(nods) Torn her posters down, full on paint fight, they're chanting, ‘get your tits out for the lads’. Girls too. It’s carnage.  Barbara looks concerned, shares a shake of the head with Elaine. Bill looks up from the coffee station.
How was Madam?
Totally lost it. (imitates Sheba) ‘Stop it! Stop it you little fucking bastards.’
You should’ve stepped in. Brian looks anxious, thinks she’s right.
He didn’t want to patronize the little lady. She’1l be alright. The bourgeoisie need a good pasting now and then, reminds ‘em where the true power resides. He lobs a tea-bag in his mug.
This time next year she’ll be Headmistress. Antonia - another teacher - explodes:
Oh Christ, will you shut up?! I’m trying to work! She gestures to a mountain of school books she’s marking.
(sarcastic) Sorry, sorry. Char, anyone? (pointedly) Babs?
Milk, no sugar.
Sweet enough?
Evidently.
Didn't her father invent inflation?
You what?
Wasn’t her dad that academic; Donald whatsit? Economics bloke, he invented the word ‘inflation’.
(lying) Oh yeah, yeah, I know who you mean.

I think you’ll find that Mrs Hart’s father was Professor Ronald Taylor. He didn’t ‘invent inflation’, he devised a theory about the relationship between inflation and consumer expectation. A silence. Brian and Elaine share a look at Barbara’s expense.

The school day over. Barbara walks through the lobby. she hears loud noises from the library and goes to look. A photocopied sign on the door: HOMEWORK CLUB. Through the window she sees TWO BOYS fighting and Sheba desperately trying to separate them. OTHER KIDS encourage fighters. It’s mayhem.

Stop this immediately! Stop it both of you or you’1l be up before the Head! Barbara waits: let Sheba suffer or be her saviour? The chaos continues - she takes a deep breath then bursts bellowing: Int. LIBRARY - CONTINUOUS
Immediate silence. She parts the boys with swift and vigo force. Sheba is hugely relieved but Barbara’s not finishe yet.
(To the boys) Outside. Now! The two boys file out. Barbara surveys the rest of the cl A BOY has a baseball cap on. Barbara points to her head, boy removes the cap from his own.

(To other kids) Get on with your work! Which they do, at once. And then Barbara marches out. Sheba is unsure whether she’s supposed to follow. Barbara gestures for her to come with. INT. CORRIDOR OUTSIDE LIBRARY — MOMENTS LATER The boys are looking at the floor, hands in pockets.
Why were they fighting, Mrs Hart?
The motive was unclear.
(To first boy) Davis I know - you’re a little thug, aren’t you? (To second boy) And who might you be? The second boy is STEVEN CONNOLLY (15).
(mumbling) Steven Connolly, Miss.
What?
Steven Connolly, Miss.
Year?
Year Ten, Miss.
(suddenly remembers ) The naked footballer. Why were you fighting? (beat) It’s a perfectly simple question.
Dunno, Miss.
You don’t know. One minute you’re an inert lump, the next you’re attempting to castrate a fellow pupil. Nothing cccurred between these two states?
No, Miss.
(cod Irish accent) Don’t be a hero, Connolly, it’s hardly da place. (pause) Yes? Brain - mouth - and speak.
(reluctantly) He was saying stuff about Miss. (nods at Sheba) He was bang out of order. This is news to Sheba.
(To Davis) What did you say?
I never said nothing-
(correcting him) ‘I didn’t say anything’. (To Connolly) What did he say? Oh, come on!
He said she’s a tart...he said he gave her one up the arse. Sheba is shocked, Barbara is not.
(To Davis) Did you indeed? Odious boy, apologize at once.
(To Sheba) Sorry, Miss.
Deputy Head in the morning. Now back in, both of you. The boys shuffle in to the library. Sheba shakes her head
Little towers of testosterone, you'll get used to them.
Thank you so much. I’d better... She gestures to the library but Barbara holds out her han
oh, sorry, we haven’t met properly, have we? Sheba Hart. Art department. They shake hands.
Barbara Covett. History. Barbara watches Sheba go back in. And smiles for the firs time.
Quite a nice voice, plummy and deep. As if her mouth was pure, as if she’d never had a filling.
Barbara and Sheba on playground duty. They smile at each other.
The complexion of a white peach. One can almost see her veins.  INT. SCHOOL CANTEEN — ANOTHER DAY
Her trendy politics are similarly transparent . Barbara, Sheba and Sue in the busy lunch queue.
We serve them best if we teach them to read, write and add. They don’t need to know about the basket weavers of Chile.
Barbara’s very keen on the basics. Sheba helps herself to some sad looking coleslaw.
(To Barbara) But when you started, didn’t you want to give them a...a real education? To help them overcome - well... (sotto) -.-the poverty of their backgrounds?
Yes of course but one soon learns that teaching is crowd control - we’re a branch of the social services. Barbara spots a boy stealing a Kit Kat.
(To boy) Put it back! Sheba looks mournful, Sue tries to rally her.

Console yourself with the gems. Every now and then you find one with an agile mind and a will to learn. That’s when it’s satisfying, when you can really make a difference. Sheba seems to really ‘hear’ this.
The rest is just cattle prod and pray. They carry their trays to a vacant table. Barbara watches Sheba intently, she seems so defeated by it all. But her sadness is beautiful to behold... [a
I can see why others are beguiled by her.
Barbara waiting outside.
But I wonder if she possesses the requisite heft? Sheba emerges pulling on her coat, surprised to see Barba there.
Fancy a coffee?

Mmm. They head off. But then Barbara spots SUE emerging from t other side of the playground. She tries to usher Sheba at speed but Sue is gaining on them. A chase! Fatally, Barbara glances back and Sheba follows suit. she sees the panting Sue and waits for her to join them - muc Barbara’s frustration. INT. GREASY CAFF — LATER Barbara smoking - ever so slightly sulking. Sue and Sheba cappuccinos. Sue mock taps the table with her spoon.
Ahem. I’ve got a bit of an announcement:
You’re leaving St George’s?
No!
(flatly) oh, you’re pregnant. Sue registers a moment of anti-climactic sadness.
That’s fantastic! Congratulations! When are you due?
June the seventh.
A summer baby, how lovely.
So you'll be taking maternity leave?
Mmm, can’t wait! Barbara nods, encouragingly.
Rest is so important.
Do you know what it is? Sheba catches Barbara’s eye and suggests she put her cigarette out. Barbara does so but only to please her.

Rog reckons it’s a boy but I'm certain it’s a girl. Aren’t they supposed to be iow slung? I can’t believe nobody noticed, I’m 14 weeks! Didn’t you see how chunky I’m getting?! Barbara notices a dab of froth on Sheba’s nose. She hands a serviette. Sheba thanks her with a smile.
Barbara and Sheba waiting outside. Sue inside buying a ho water bottle.
Do you want to come for lunch, on Sunday?
Where?
To mine, to our house.
Won't you be with your family?
Yes but you’re very welcome. It’s no big deal, I’1l just do a lasagne or something.
I adore lasagne.
Barbara is almost blushing.
Bliss! Women's wear. A SHOP ASSISTANT nods as Barbara discusses virtues of a skirt she’s interested in.

A merry flag on the Arctic wilderness of my calendar. Shoe Department. Five different pairs for consideration. To ANOTHER SHOP ASSISTANT’s relief Barbara finally plumps a pair of black, low heelers with a strap.

BARBARA’S FLAT - EVENING Barbara walks into the bedroom in her new heels. She twir in front of the mirror, ‘catching herself’.

The art of it is seeming not to. Barbara carefully spray starches her white blouse. INT/EXT. BARBARA’S CAR/STREET - SUNDAY Barbara cruising down the street looking for a space. Her Polo incongrucus amongst the smart cars already parked.

She stands there, pristine in her grey skirt, white blous new black heels. She holds a bunch of flowers. She composes herself and presses the bell. No sound. She tries again. Waits. Nothing. She tries the knocker. The door is opened by a tall, slightly shaggy MAN in his fifties.
I think I’ve come to the wrong house.
(smiles) . No, you're bang on. I’m Richard. Come in!
I’m so sorry, I thought—
That I’‘d be twenty years younger and twice as handsome. He helps her out of her coat.
Sorry, were you out there long? The bell’s knackered. /lo He dumps her coat over the bannister. The hall is clutte with junk, boots, bicycles etc.
Bash! A flustered Sheba pokes her head out the kitchen.
Hi, Barbara! The kitchen’s on fire! Richard raises an eyebrow and ushers Barbara: INT. SITTING ROOM — CONTINUOUS
Oh, what a splendid room.
What can I get you? We’re semi-pro drinkers here; absinthe, hooch, pick your poison.
Could I have a dry sherry, please?
Erm...I might have some apricot brandy knocking around...
Or a dry white wine?

Done. Have a seat. Barbara takes in the room; the look is ‘battered bourgeoi the big sofas, the bare boards, paintings, overflowing bookshelves, Sunday papers. She sits in an armchair and finds herself semi-recumbent is its hidden depth. A GIRL of 15 drifts in. She quietly observes as Barbara struggles to sit up.
You must be Polly.
(shrugs) Must be. Hi.
I’m Barbara.
Hi, Barbara. Polly’s contempt is instantaneous but she makes a vague s at concealing it. She flops into a sofa, sips her bottle of Evian.
Are you going somewhere?
Excuse me?
You’re all poshed up.
Oh...I have an appointment. Later. In town. (beat) Have you always lived here?
Mum inherited it. It’s her little joke -
(coming in) - I only married her for the property. He carries an opened bottle of wine and glasses.
(To Polly) Morning. He hands drinks round.
Did Pete go? Polly nods.
He was welcome to stay.
He’s not really into lunch.
(To Barbara) cheers.
Mom. What is it?
A witless Chardonnay.
Are you interested in wine?
Only the drinking part. You?
Well, I spent a portion of the summer on the Amalfi coast and I became- She's interrupted by loud thumps as someone thunders down wooden stairs.
Here’s trouble... BEN runs in and leaps head first onto the sofa.
Easy, Rocky! Easy! Ben is twelve. He has Down’s Syndrome. Barbara didn’t kno She watches Richard and his son playfully fighting with e other.
I'd anticipated a suave, young lawyer and two perfect poppets. Not so. She's married some crumbling patriarch - he’s nearly as old as me!
Everyone sat at the big table, eating their slightly burn lasagne and salad- Barbara has a tiny portion, almost untouched. She conceal with a large lettuce leaf.
And then there’s the daughter; a pocket princess. Polly picks at her food, uninterested.
And finally, a somewhat tiresome court jester. Ben wolfs his food down, makin hi s i habitually. 1 g a mess which Sheba wipes up
I’m going to be a wizard.
Oh? ...Is that when you‘re a growh up...?
No, he’s just been cast in his school play! Ben beams with pride as Sheba hugs him.

(critic’s voice) Amongst next year’s cultural highlights I greatly look forward to Benjamin Hart in the key role of ‘The Wizard’. Indeed I find myself to be beside myself with anticipation for this doubtless auspicious stage debut. As Richard continues...
A rogue image swam through me, hubby’s pruney old mouth pursed at Sheba’s breast.
Sheba and Ben are dancing to ‘Funky Kingston’ by Toots an the Maytals up loud on the Bang & Olufsen.
After lunch a rather mortifying family tradition... Sheba’s quite drunk and having a ball. Richard moves to h own slower rhythm amusing the delighted Ben.

They do things differently in bourgeois bohemia. Polly and Barbara, sour bedfellows on the sofa, both mort embarrassed. Polly offers Barbara a fag which she accepts gratefully. 0  As the music continues Barbara's expression changes: her admiration for Sheba’s enthusiasm, her love for her son, natural warmth, her beauty... As Sheba dances Barbara is almost overcome by her. Richard grooves up and encourages Polly to join in. She b him away and draws on her Marlboro Light. Now he tries to haul Barbara to her feet, she protests but he's relentles Polly - the traitor - ‘helps’ her up. Barbara stands in the centre of the room. An awkward mome as she half raises her arms for a formal dance but Richar not there to reciprocate. Ben grabs Barbara’s hand and they dance. A mobile phone rings - unheard by all except Polly. She passes it to her mother. Sheba goes out into the hallway to speak. Her conversatio seems intense, possibly furtive...

Richard and Ben are playing French Cricket. The garden is large, rambling and overgrown. Barbara and Sheba head to a partially concealed SUMMER HO at the back. Sheba carries coffee and biscuits on a tray.
I’m sorry I didn’t tell you about Ben - not that it’s - just sometimes people don’t quite know how to react.
Wot at ali, he’s charming. (beat) Has it been difficult?
Well, you just get on with it, don’t you? Polly’s the tricky one but who isn’t at fifteen? I was impossible.
Surely not!
Wilful and flighty - lethal combination. You?
I think I was rather quiet.
Did you want children?
Mmm. But I never found the time. They reach the large, bashed up Summer house.
How wonderful.

Richard took me away for our wedding anniversary, years ago. When we got back it was here, as if by magic. They go inside. INT. SUMMER HOUSE -— CONTINUOUS. Barbara sips her coffee, conscious she’s in Sheba’s ‘lair and feeling privileged to be so. The ‘studio’ is full of Sheba’s pottery works, drawings a sketches. A comfy, messy den of curios and artefacts.
It was supposed to be my studio but it’s more of a refuge really.

A room of one’s own. There’s a big stack of vinyl LP’s and 7” singles by the stereo. A large photo pinned to the wall amongst a collag other images. Sheba as a teemager with a gang of friends, exotically dressed in post punk splendour - heavy eye mak etc. Threatening, confident, sexy.
Is this you?
Well...it was. Barbara admires some glazed plates on a shelf.
I like these. Such vibrant colours. ae  3
Take one. Take two. Have the lot actually.
Oh, I couldn’t possibly. Sheba takes a few down and hands them to her.
Honestly, no one else wants them.
I’ll treasure them. Too intense, too much - Barbara knows it. Sheba starts wrapping the plates in old newspaper. Barbar carefully sits on a rickety chair.
It must be exhausting, running a family and teaching as well?

I can’t wait for term to end. Roll on Christmas and a month of sod all. Oh, I shouldn’t have kidded myself I could teach. I’ve spent the last ten years looking after Ben - I was desperate to get out and do something - finally we got him into this great local school and I'm free to work and... She shakes her head at the difficulty of it all.
You’‘re going to be a terrific teacher.
Thanks, but I’m bloody hopeless and everyone knows it. She finishes with the plates and flops into the shabby, o sofa.
Children are feral, don’t let them sense your anxiety.
How do you cope?
Oh, I’m a battle-axe. I’m not popular but at least they respect me.
Well, you’re popular with me. Barbara smiles. A hint of therapist and patient. Barbara her chair, Sheba on the couch - the hip bone exposed, the ankles, her hands waving as she continues to talk.

She spoke of her ‘vile’ mother, her grief over the death of her father, the glory days when Richard scooped her up and then jettisoned his wife and children for what she called a ‘non stop fuckfest.’ It's a peculiar trait of the privileged: immediate, incautious intimacy. But Sheba went well beyond the tendencies of her class. She was utterly candid; a novice confessing to the mother superior. It’s getting dark outside. Richard and Ben have gone in. The atmosphere in the Summer House is intimate now, siste Sheba concludes her long speech:

But you know, marriage and kids, it’s wonderful but it doesn’t give you meaning. It gives you an imperative but it doesn’t help you...my father used to say - you know on the tube - ‘Mind The Gap’. Barbara looks a little confused.
I dunno, the distance between life as you dream it and... (softly) ...life as it is. Barbara stares at her, rapt.
I know exactly what you mean.
CLOSE: A gold star on a page of Barbara’s diary-
A gold star day! She sticks the star down with her thumb.

I aiways knew we’d be friends. Out mutual reserve inhibited us but now it is manifest; a spiritual recognition! As she continues to write we see the strangely anodyne possessions of her life: the trinkets, the cat toys, etc.
Assembly. Pabblem making announcements. The PUPILS sit in rows. STAFF on a raised platform.

‘S’ and I share the ability to see through the quotidian awfulness of things. In a different (better) age we would be ladies of leisure; lunching together, visiting galleries, travelling, putting the world to rights. Barbara sits behind Sheba who is casually twirling the ha at the back of her neck. A strand falls into Barbara’s la
We would be companions. The strand of hair taut between her fingers.

The school carol concert. The last day of term. A school band on stage doing a ‘rap’ version of ‘Hark The Herald Angels Sing’. Toasting each other, the hoods, the attitude. Sue Hodge is conducting them, gleefully. Pabblem beams. This is what his school is all about. Brian is into the groove. He wears a Tottenham Hotspur baseball cap and stuffs a mince pie in his gob. Gita fakes enjoyment — in common with many other staff_ The kids are allowed to ‘dress down’. Some are in festiv fancy dress. Some clap along. Others throw food around. Barbara sits at the end of a row. An empty seat beside he Bill tries to sit in it but Barbara says it’s reserved. She looks around for Sheba. Not here. she slips out of th room. INT. BARBARA’S CLASSROOM. Barbara goes over to the window and looks out. It’s dark outside. There’s a dim light on in the Art Studio. INT. SCHOOL CORRIDOR. Barbara heads for the exit. Christmas decorations and children’s art fill the walls. The rap music echoes down the empty corridor. EXT. PLAYGROUND. The playground in darkness. Barbara heads towards the Art Studio. The light still on. But then it goes out. Barbara waits for Sheba to emerge. But she doesn’t. Now Barbara approaches, perplexed... She hears a noise - a chair scraping back - male laughter ‘shhh’ - silence. Barbara sneaks up to a window. Standing on tip toes she c just see inside. Darkness. Footsteps. A murmur... And then...a match...a tiny flare of light. And then an orange glow - a cigarette. Still she can’t see properly, her eyes beginning to adjus She can make out Sheba’s desk now... and Sheba sitting on her chair at the desk... er shirt undone to the waist... Barbara holds her breath. alo  ot Sheba’s mouth - she’s saying something... And now the orange glow comes back into view. She sees a white shirt. A man holding a cigarette. Sheba gesturing - something to do with the cigarette... The man stands in front of Sheba. A playful exchange of words. He puts the cigarette out. Sheba nods and then undoes his zip. Pulls him towards her Barbara watching as Sheba gives head. The man comes quickly. Sheba’s hand on his mouth, silenci him. Barbara’s hand on her own mouth. Distant applause and stamping. The carol concert’s finish The lovers hear the applause. They kiss passionately. Sheba buttons her shirt. He goes to the door and slips ou Barbara edges round the building to see him...it’s that b fifteen year old - STEVEN CONNOLLY. Barbara grips the wall for support. Steven heads towards the school gates pulling his coat on lugging his school bag over his shoulder. The Art Studio lights flash on. Barbara turns back, sees Sheba picking something from the floor - a fag butt. She wraps it in paper and pockets it. CHILDREN and STAFF start streaming out the school doors. Barbara alone for a moment before she’s engulfed.
Barbara sat in her armchair, still in shock. Thinking.
Sheba and Ben loading the car with their shopping. Sheba humps a box of mineral water into the boot. Her mobile rings, she answers.
It’s Barbara. I need to talk to you about Steven Connolly. Sheba freezes. The best she can do:
Who...?
A thin smile from Barbara.
Let’s not, shall we? I’m afraid I’ve learnt of your ‘activities’. Sheba - horrified - before she can respond:

Doubtless you're aware you could go to jail. I’m driving to Eastbourne tonight, I’m spending Christmas with my sister. I’1l be with you at five. Barbara puts the phone down. Silence. Then, a strange CROAK. Her cat, Portia, has vomited at he feet. EXT. SHEBA’S HOUSE - EARLY EVENING Before Barbara can knock Sheba comes out in her coat.
Let’s go to the pub, OK?
I brought you this, for all of you.  a Barbara hands her a bottle of sherry. Sheba looks at. it it’s a bomb, then deposits it inside the door.

They walk in silence. Sheba sick with fear. Barbara has t double her pace to keep up. They arrive at the pub. It’s festooned with festive cheer couple of drunks barge past them singing carols. Barbara gestures to a wooden table with benches, chained the wall outside - quieter.

Sheba and Barbara sat with their drinks - a dry sherry an hefty scotch. Barbara lights a cigarette. Sheba is shakin with fear (and cold). ‘SHEBA So...when...when will you tell them? Barbara is inscrutable, relishing her power.
I need to know the circumstances. You must inform me of everything. Sheba takes a slug of her drink, her only option to compl
Actually, you were there, when I first noticed him... EXT. PLAYGROUND — FLASHBACK A roar. Steven scores his goal then whips his shirt off a points in glory at Sheba.
I think you gave him a telling off.
No, I gave him a slight ticking off. Sheba gives Steven a little smile-

Be dedicated his goal to me. It was just a sweet thing, it amused me. Steven runs off past Barbara who tells him to put his shi back on. But Sheba continues to gaze at the boy - his smooth skin, hips, his muscles moving as he pulls the shirt over his h

I’1l look at them in class. You do Art, don't you?
I’m not allowed... (embarrassed) I'm special needs. I gotta do extra reading instead.
You did these at home? He nods and hands her the envelope. Sheba looks at the boy’s ‘work’. Pencil sketches of fruit can of coke, a woman vaguely like herself, his own hands.
These are good. You can draw. Steven is thrilled.

Yeah, they’re a right bastard.
You have to really study them, the bone structure...look... She does a quick sketch of his hands. She's talented, def Her sketch is simple but clear.

Sheba with Ted Mawson. Kids streaming past between lesson

ch, they’re all talented!
Sheba and Barbara at their table. Barbara looks steely-
